I really can not blame some of the managers because that is the type of leadership that the corporate guys from home office taught them. review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros:
Good compensation for salaried IT full time IT role, decent benefits. A truly friendly work environment without as much negativity as other places I have worked. IT group manages change decently well. Management tries to communicate and is generally open - I do feel like the managers care about me as a person more than some other places. The company has survived the pandemic relatively well financially and was able to bring back most full time people who were furloughed as well as some contractors relatively quickly - I do think furloughs were unavoidable when over half of the retail locations were shut down at one point or another. The craziness of some of the work that had to happen for the pandemic was acknowledged and they tried to manage work-life balance and rewards at a time when that was very difficult to do well.
Training program for hourly sales does seem designed to help people succeed. As used car salesmen go, they are more open and honest than most - people who work there do buy cars from there.
cons:
Too much separation between what the main headquarters thinks is happening in the stores/contact centers and what is actually happening - executives simply do not have control over what is happening in other physical locations. Managers on power trips run the show, and while it is clear that they are trying to be diverse it isn't truly working yet and the boys network is alive and well. Some legacy tech is holding the company back from its full potential and IT investment is somewhat scattered - I would proritize other projects/hiring over some of the things that have gotten investment. 
For covid-19 if they didn't HAVE to shut down a particular location by government mandate, they didn't, and some of the social distancing practices are a joke. For a company that makes a big deal about caring for its employees, I did not feel they took my safety seriously but rather cared more about looking like they were doing something more than actually helping. People at headquarters are safely working at home while asking everyone else to physically come in - obviously some roles like the service departments can't be done remotely, but they could do more remotely in other roles.
Seems like the usual sucking up and playing favorites around people getting promoted to management roles - in over a year I haven't seen anyone move from hourly to management yet (and there have been management spots open). Promotions seem to take a while.
Hourly roles seem somewhat micromanaged - there are particular sales scripts, strict rules about what can be on a desk, etc.
Advice to Management
Stop sweeping problems with legacy tech under the rug - bite the bullet and upgrade things properly like you should have before some of the operational changes happening pre-covid. Get your regional managers and below under control - keep tabs on what's happening in the field day to day. Upper level managers seem ok but there is rot in the middle. Don't micro-manage people too heavily in the hourly roles - you make a big deal about hiring the right people, so trust them to do the right thing.

pros:
Pay is on-par with other big box retailers, Offers medical, dental, vision, 401k, monthly bonus, stock grants.

Demo vehicle you can personally drive after 4 years of service in SM role.

It's a great place to work when times are good. You can make a lot of money if you and the Sales Manager team that you work with are competent. 

You can stay busy all the time. The customer traffic is often plentiful. 

Some really great people work there. At the store level, there is usually a sense of team spirit and you will work around people that are usually willing to pitch in to help when needed.
cons:
Firstly, this is not ""retail-adjacent" or "better than retail." It's a mix of traditional car sales and retail. 

As one of nearly 500+ Sales managers in the company, you are just a number. Your store manager may care, but he is going to be at the whim of the RVP. Sometimes you will be selected to "choose" to go to another store, and the politics are such that you will be looked upon negatively if you don't go "for the company." 

Hours are unnecessarily long (min. 10 hour shifts). You are busy every minute of that time. Typically you have the minimum coverage possible (they even eliminated some SM positions a while ago for "efficiency" (some found new positions, some were just laid off). If you are looking for a job that encourages you to spend time with your family, this isn't it. And don't schedule anything on a set day of the week, your schedule rotates and you'll be working some of those days.

When the business is having a tough time, you're getting a tough time from your manager. Stuff rolls downhill and CarMax is no exception. You have a daily budget for how many cars you're supposed to sell and at the end of the month that performance factors into your bonus and review for that month).

Little consideration is given for any kind of training. While their training programs exist, as usual it is simply a lack of execution. You will be asked to conduct training each morning for the sales team that were haphazardly constructed the week before by people who don't work in any store.

Constant change. Sometimes it's for the better, sometimes not. If you are looking for a job that's consistent, this isn't it. 

One last thing: Though it only affect Sales Manager indirectly, it should be said: The pay for SCs is consistent across the country; the cost of living is not. In low cost of living states you can make a decent living. If you live in a market like LA or Boston, you cannot survive on only SC pay. Also, it is only commission with a draw, not any set hourly wage that you don't have to pay back. All of this means that you will likely find it difficult to keep SCs, and you will have constant churn. New people to find and hire, to train, etc. This is a major sticking point for SCs; in more expensive markets they will often be struggling financially and unhappy because of it. I would make sure you know this if going to work at CarMax in a more expensive area.

I recommended to the RVP that we close the store immediately so people could get home safely. It took 3 hours to get the okay to close, and by then the roads were terrible; luckily, I sent all the staff I could have home. I was the last person in the store, left, and was in an accident in my CarMax demo vehicle (it was not a faulted accident due to weather). If my recommendation was followed, I would have been home. Even better, the RVP wrote me up for getting into the accident.

Another downside is Carmax allows no room for creative problem-solving or independent thought. Everything must be done in a box-checking manner, with no exceptions.

Overall, the company is very disorganized and doesn't value their employees very much. They say they do but always demonstrate the opposite. For example, upon my resignation, the company took about 3 weeks to get my final paycheck to me. They also lost my sales license. When I asked where it was, I got multiple answers. Finally, I was told, "get a new one from DMV. Sorry, don't know what to tell you". This is just poor accountability.

At the end of the day, Carmax wants everyone to fit into a mold and be the same because they want to "give every customer the same experience". There's a major flaw in that thinking. You see, not every customer is the same. Once again, this is a classic example of Carmax treating people as just bodies and not as people.

 If you want to work in car sales, do yourself a favor and work at a regular dealership and learn real skills from real professionals. This is merely a retail sales job like Best Buy disguised as car sales.

Pros
Potential to make lots of money working nights and weekends. Having tools like salesforce, carmax app, and outlook email to keep in touch with your customer it makes it easier to be able to follow up, work remotely so that you can keep in contact and stay on top of customers requests and appointments. You can come in to work to sell a vehicle on your days off if needed.
Cons
You may need to work extra hours to become successful as a part time sales consultant but that is only a CON if you don't know how to balance your work schedule. You are sometimes at the mercy of your customers time.
Advice to Management
In sales, your only empowered to handle up to a certain level of customer service. When you give your customers great service they turn to you for help, and when you try to include other departments to help out your customer, you are pushed aside instead of partnering with the sales consultant to better understand the customers situation, and offering feedback to the sales consultant and customer about the next steps, which reflects poorly on how customer service is truly handled. This maybe reflected upon one store in particular, but it should be an example to others about how this process needs to change. 

In a company that is all about providing the best customer service, it all about how you handle a customers situation after the sale no matter the issue, the company needs to be able to stand behind their product, employees, and customer. Don't look for the cheapest way out, if there is an issue with the quality control of how many customers are returning a vehicle due to mechanic reasons, there needs to be a discussion or investigate with the manager of that department to resolve or diminish the issue and prevent these issues further. In the end it all comes down to the quality in the product in which you are selling, which also reflects how the sales consultants gets paid which drives more business to the store. My advice to sales managers is backup your sales consultants, they are trying to create the best customer service they can provide but may need to turn to you for help. Help them where you can, go above and beyond your role, don't be afraid to stand up to another manager from another department to have a conversation about whats happening in their departments. Come together and think outside the box on solutions to problems that you see within your department, or other departments.
